top_comment.text:
couldn't care less about the online multiplayer,  to me playing sp trying 
to unlock and beat all the different cups is where its at imo,  i will say 
one thing about it tho,  as great as it is it gets brutally hard as you 
advance,  the rainbow tracks are just as annoying as ever and sometimes the 
AI goes a bit overboard with the weapons,  all i can say to somebody who's 
not played it yet and planning on trying it out,  don't let 100cc fool you 
into thinking its an easy game cause once you reach 150cc the AI stops 
messing around with you so you'd better hone some skill.﻿

top_comment.text:
You know guys, I normally dispise Mario games and am one of those types who 
says "oh, ANOTHER Mario game", so when this one came out I just looked at 
it and said "well what the f*ck is new/different this time?", I know that 
the basics for Mario Kart works and that you shouldn't fix what ain't 
broken, but still, when you release a new game, I want something new, cuz 
otherwise I see no reason to not just stick with the previous installment.

.........then I watched this review and a few hours of gameplay footage 
from BrainScratchComms, and I haven't taken my temperature yet, but I was 
actually somewhat impressed by what I saw, how the levels are designed with 
twists and twerks and up-side-down. I might even get this one :o﻿
top_comment.author: PikaLink91

+nicky steve I normally don't, but Mario is an exception, I just can't help 
judging his games on the cover.
But regardless, you say that new things don't matter.. well, maybe not so 
much when you have already established a formula that works, but to me the 
anti-gravity thing was "new things" enough for me that I was totally sucked 
in:) (haven't got it yet though, my wallet is ackin' after I got Kirby 
Triple Deluxe).
comments.author: PikaLink91

comments.text:
I'm a die hard mario kart fan, and when I saw this is was pissed. I was 
looking forward to it so much, and all I get is a upside down wooo hooo 
thing. When it came out I couldn't care less, but I basically beat all my 
wii u games and I needed to find a new game. So at the store the owner 
highly recommended it and I thought, you know what, fine, I ll probably 
hate it though, and I got home and played it and I'm speechless. I realized 
that new things don't matter, when you can just improve, and I mean IMPROVE 
the old. The anti gravity is pretty cool, I like the scenery actually, but 
the graphics and the orgasmic item changes, this is my second favourite 
mario kart game and my favourite game on wii u. 11/10 SONT JUDGE A GAME BY 
ITS COVER XD
comments.author: nicky steve

comments.text:
+PikaLink91 I will meet you halfway and agree that the modern 2-D Mario 
games are released too frequently and they're pretty derivative. It's 
ironic because New Mario U is probably the best, most creative 2-D Mario 
since the classics, but it released just months after the mediocre New 
Mario 2 and that kind of ruined NSMBU.

I stand by my original comment otherwise.
comments.author: Relytia

comments.text:
+Relytia But New Mario Bros. U is just as rehash of New Mario Bros. Wii. 
It's just that the games come out so frequently that... never mind.
comments.author: PikaLink91

comments.text:
I always find it funny when people assume that just because a game has 
Mario in it, it must be a rehash. It's kind of silly to assume that just 
because it has Mario it's just a rehash. Seriously, the Mario 3-D 
platformers are totally different from the 2-D platformers, which are 
totally different from the Mario RPG games (and even then, Paper Mario is 
very different from Mario & Luigi), which are totally different from the 
Kart racers, which are totally different from the Mario sports games, etc., 
etc., etc.

Hell, no reasonable person would even say any two 3-D Mario platformers are 
too similar. Sunshine is a totally different beast from the Galaxy games, 
which is totally different from 3D Land/World. 

Whenever I read people bash Nintendo for rehashing because a game has *insert 
famous Nintendo character here*, all I can read is "HURRR 
DURRRRRRRRRRRRRRR". lol
comments.author: Relytia

comments.text:
+PikaLink91
2d mario is irrelevant in a mario kart review.
comments.author: Sato

comments.text:
When you put it that way, it IS kind of a silly saying, but I think you 
know what people, including me, mean when we say "yet another Mario game", 
cuz yeah, duuh it's a Mario game like you said, it wouldn't be called Mario 
if it wasn't Mario. But what we mean is that Mario games rarely does 
anything new-- on the surface. To me, Mario Kart 8 looked like a new Mario 
Kart Wii, just with a new coat of paint, but when I dug into it, I saw how 
innovative the stage designs were. That's not often the case though, and in 
most cases, i don't feel that there's reason to buy the next 2D Mario game 
when I already have New Luigi Bros., unless each game brings something 
notably new to the table.
comments.author: PikaLink91

comments.text:
At least its not call of duty which I could call the exact same game with 
a  different coat of paint. A new game every year, literally, every year. 
Last time I checked a good game takes time to make, which would explain 
alot. I duno what you expect from mario, yeah it looks and plays like mario 
kart, but thats proberly why its called mario kart, if it didnt play like 
mario kart and people bought it for mario kart then say goodbye consumer 
base, its silly saying its ANOTHER MARIO GAME because if it wasnt it would 
be called crash bandicoot or klonoa. Pointless statement if you ask me

top_comment.text:
Some objective things that are wrong with this game (don't argue, these 
aren't opinions)
- No horizontal split screen
- No on-screen map (Seriously?)
- Literally no options to customize the game or controls﻿
top_comment.author: Shadowfied

comments.text:
Woo! They are really patching to add an on-screen map! Wasn't expecting 
them to do that actually. Good going Nintendo! - Although, it should still 
have been there from the beginning..
comments.author: Shadowfied

comments.text: +shadowstupidguy all of your complaints are wrong
comments.author: Portal pig

comments.text:
+A - Kuma I was talking about the game, not a mode. I appreciate that the *VERSUS 
RACES* are *VERY* customizable, however, having a settings / options menu 
for a video game for global variables and settings is a necessity. 
Controls, sensitivity, flipped camera controls and not to mention freaking 
audio. Usually, even the most shitty games have audio controls. A high 
budget amazing game like this should as well. In this same menu, I would 
appreciate "Splitscreen: Horizontal / Vertical" - "On-Screen Map - On / 
Off" etc, actually, the map should just be controlled by an in-race input, 
like Mario Kart 64.
You know what, even Mario Kart 64 had the ability to switch on and off 
music by using the C Buttons WHILE RACING.
I recently began studying game development, my groups first game has a wide 
variety of options; http://puu.sh/9F0SA/ad61f662a0.jpg
This menu can also be scrolled down to reveal even more settings.
comments.author: Shadowfied

that's what you're referring to then i have no idea what you're talking 
about.

comments.author: Remo Santangeli

comments.text:
Well, MK8's Battle Mode concept seems to have a different approach than 
what other Battle Modes in the series went for. Which is why it doesn't 
work very well when played solo or with friends - whereas Battle Mode was a 
blast to play that way in other installments. When I played it for the 
first time (alone, that is), I kinda understood why so many reviewers are 
downright bashing on this mode, but when I played it online, I actually had 
a good amount of fun, as the other players (which obviously, but worth 
noting, were not CPUs) were actually attempting to play it competitively. 
MK8's Battle Mode might not be the best concept in the series, but when it 
IS played properly, it DOES work.

because of how many end up flying around the track at once. I wouldn't mind 
if they at least brought some of the old arenas back but they didn't.
comments.author: Ludodave

captions.text:
It's no secret that for Wii U owners, it's
been kind of a bumpy ride. And sometimes,

bumpy rides are the most fun rides, but...this
hasn't been that kind of ride. Seems like

there's been obstacles around every turn.
And every time it seemed to build some momentum,

some jerk showed up, with a blue shell. There
goes the momentum.

But now? Nintendo's console is finally hittin'
the gas. And it's gotten a speed boost, from

this phenomenal racing game. Pull up to the
starting line, Wii U fans.
Because this ride's about to get fun.

And that's always been the operative word
with Mario Kart. Fun. From its debut on the

Super NES, to its four-player breakthrough
on the Nintendo 64, to its mega-popular Wii

version...Mario Kart's fun. With every generation,
and with every batch of consoles, I don't

think there's a game I look forward to more...than
Mario Kart. Because Mario Kart lasts the entire

generation, you know? You play Mario Kart
with your friends 'til the day the next one
comes out.
The only difference with this one is...

Mario Kart 8 is so good, it'll last even longer.
This one's destined to be a classic, one you'll

go back to even after the next one comes out.
Now, I'm not saying it's the best Mario Kart,
but...
It's definitely one of them.

Now why is that? Well, there's a lot of reasons.
But more than anything else...Nintendo really

tweaked the engine, so to speak. They made
a lot of changes. Some minor, some not as

minor, but they come together to make this
one of the most distinct Mario Karts in years.

And, while they were messing around under
the hood, they seriously tightened up everything.

Every functional element of Mario Kart 8...is
perfect. There's not a single broken belt,

or loose muffler, or busted gasket, or...whatever
else goes wrong with cars.

So it's both new and refined. And it plays
better than ever.

And to see that dual approach in action, just
take a look at the items. I mean, it makes

some simple additions, with new stuff like
the Piranha Plant, and the Boomerang Flower...but

it also refines the items system. So now,
those weapons that affect everyone on the

track are less common. I mean, there's still
lightning and Blooper ink...it's still Mario
Kart.

But for the most part, if you want to hit
somebody with an item, you'd better be close

to them. And that's reflected in the new items,
as well. The Piranha Plant, the boomerang...they're

only effective when you're near another driver.
So where a game like Mario Kart Wii could

be this constant hammering of weapons from
racers who aren't even close to you...

Mario Kart 8 kind of re-balances things...back
toward skill.

At least, a little bit. I mean, come on, it's
still Mario Kart.

And that balance is a big part of the reason
Mario Kart 8 feels so distinct. It balances

change with refinement, fairness with wackiness...and
also new with old. In fact, it reminds me

of Mario 3D World in that way. How it manages
to incorporate old ideas into new ideas, and

make them seem fresh. Like, it brings back
the coins from Super Mario Kart, which increase

your kart's speed...but they also unlock new
parts, to customize your karts.

And it's the track design, too. Shy Guy Falls
has you racing up a waterfall, before heading

straight back down...creating this crazy sensation
of height that takes you all the way back

to DK Mountain on the GameCube. Only DK Mountain
didn't have antigravity sections.

So every time there's something that takes
you back in time, Mario Kart 8 somehow does

something...that makes it feel new. And that's
one of the coolest things about this game.

Of course, there are a few things about Mario
Kart 8...that aren't as cool. In fact, there's

a couple things about Mario Kart 8 that are
baffling. Like, the roster is great, there

are 30 racers, do we really need five babies?
Like, Baby Rosalina isn't even a thing that's

real. Then there's Metal Mario...and Pink
Gold Peach? Not Birdo, or Diddy Kong, or Professor
E. Gadd...

Pink. Gold. Peach. Sounds like genetically
modified fruit.

But a couple wasted roster spots? That's forgivable.
What might not be...is the fact that Mario

Kart 8 completely butchers the Battle Mode.
Like, to the point where it's almost unplayable.

See, instead of those usual battle arenas...you
just battle on the regular tracks. And it

doesn't even remotely work, which is the one
thing about Mario Kart 8 that really, legitimately
sucks.

But fortunately, this is an amazing multiplayer
game otherwise. Four player split-screen has

always been my favorite way to go, but Mario
Kart 8 also plays great online. Now, it's

simple, perhaps to a fault...but it's super
easy to hook up with friends, and it runs
beautifully.

Oh, and speaking of beautiful...Mario Kart
8 is so that. Awesome music, creative tracks,

vibrant colors...gorgeous graphics. And you
know, the game uses that to its advantage

in one of its coolest new features. So after
each race, you get to see highlights from

that race. And the best part is that you can
edit them, and adjust them...and even play

them in slow motion. That's when you see how
beautiful this game really is.

And there's a lot you can do with the highlights,
too. You can actually upload them directly

to YouTube, or you can use Mario Kart TV to
watch your recents, your favorites, and even

other people's clips. You can even leave comments
on their videos from the GamePad, which is

awesome. It's just a perfect implementation
of the Miiverse community.

And the highlights are a lot of fun to play
with.

There's that word again. Fun. It's something
you always go back to when you talk about

Mario Kart. If there's ever been a series
of games that's given me as many memories,

and good times with friends, and as much...fun,
as this one...I can't think of it. Mario Kart

is just fun. And that's no different with
this one. But it's also a different Mario
Kart. A newer Mario Kart.
A better Mario Kart.

And I'm thrilled with it, for everything it
is. But I'm excited about it...for all the

fun, and the memories it has in store. I think
I'm gonna get even more than usual...from
Mario Kart 8.

title: CGR Undertow - MARIO KART 8 review for Nintendo Wii U
